rdfs:label: UCBLogo
ns:common.topic.description: UCBLogo, also known as Berkeley Logo, is closest to a de facto standard Logo programming language with its facilities for handling lists, files, I/O, and recursion in scripts, and can be used to teach most computer science concepts, as UC Berkeley lecturer Brian Harvey did in his Computer Science Logo Style trilogy. For tertiary level teaching, however, Logo has been superseded by Scheme, and scripting languages.

ns:common.document.text: UCBLogo is a free Logo implementation developed by Brian Harvey and his students at the University of California, Berkeley. Like many other implementations, it provides a Logo interpreter with tail call elimination. It was written in the C programming language and runs on Windows, Mac OS X, DOS, as well as various Unix-like operating systems, such as Linux and FreeBSD.

ns:type.object.name: UCBLogo
